rawFindings.title: Missing Content-Security-Policy Header
rawFindings.description: No CSP header found. This makes the application more susceptible to XSS attacks.

rawFindings.title: Missing X-Frame-Options Header
rawFindings.description: The X-Frame-Options header is missing, potentially allowing clickjacking attacks.

rawFindings.title: Missing X-Content-Type-Options Header
rawFindings.description: Missing X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff header. Browsers may MIME-sniff responses.

rawFindings.title: Missing Referrer-Policy Header
rawFindings.description: No Referrer-Policy set. Sensitive data in URLs may leak via the Referer header.

rawFindings.title: Missing Permissions-Policy Header
rawFindings.description: No Permissions-Policy header. Browser features like camera/microphone are not explicitly restricted.

interpretedFindings.title: Missing Content Security Policy (CSP)
interpretedFindings.description: The application lacks a Content Security Policy header, which is a critical defense-in-depth mechanism against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. Without CSP, attackers who find XSS vulnerabilities can inject and execute arbitrary JavaScript, steal session tokens, or perform actions on behalf of users.
interpretedFindings.impact: If an XSS vulnerability exists anywhere in the application, attackers can fully exploit it to steal credentials, perform unauthorized actions, or redirect users to malicious sites. CSP would limit the damage even if XSS occurs.
reproductionSteps: Inspect response headers for the main document
interpretedFindings.suggestedFix: Implement a strict Content Security Policy in your Next.js application. Start with a restrictive policy and gradually relax as needed. For Next.js 13+, add security headers in next.config.js or middleware.

interpretedFindings.title: Missing Clickjacking Protection (X-Frame-Options)
interpretedFindings.description: The application does not set X-Frame-Options or CSP frame-ancestors directive, allowing the site to be embedded in iframes on malicious domains. Attackers can overlay invisible iframes to trick users into clicking on sensitive actions (clickjacking).
interpretedFindings.impact: Attackers can embed your finance application in a malicious site and use UI redressing techniques to trick users into performing unintended actions like transferring funds, changing settings, or authorizing transactions.
reproductionSteps: Create a test HTML page with: <iframe src='https://atmando-finance.vercel.app/'></iframe>
Open the HTML file in a browser
Confirm the application loads successfully in the iframe
This proves the site can be framed by any domain
interpretedFindings.suggestedFix: Add X-Frame-Options header set to DENY or SAMEORIGIN. For modern browsers, also include frame-ancestors in CSP (which supersedes X-Frame-Options). For a finance application, DENY is recommended unless you specifically need iframe embedding.

interpretedFindings.title: Missing Security Headers Bundle (X-Content-Type-Options, Referrer-Policy, Permissions-Policy)
interpretedFindings.description: Three additional security headers are missing: X-Content-Type-Options prevents MIME-sniffing attacks, Referrer-Policy controls information leakage through referrer headers, and Permissions-Policy restricts browser feature access. While individually low risk, together they represent defense-in-depth gaps.
interpretedFindings.impact: X-Content-Type-Options: Browsers might misinterpret file types, potentially executing malicious content. Referrer-Policy: Sensitive data in URLs (tokens, IDs) may leak to third parties. Permissions-Policy: Unnecessary browser features remain accessible, increasing attack surface.
reproductionSteps: Open DevTools > Network > Select main document
interpretedFindings.suggestedFix: Add all three headers as part of a comprehensive security headers configuration. These are straightforward to implement and provide meaningful security improvements with no functional impact.

topIssues: Implement Content Security Policy to prevent XSS exploitation
Add X-Frame-Options/frame-ancestors to prevent clickjacking attacks
Configure complete security headers bundle (X-Content-Type-Options, Referrer-Policy, Permissions-Policy)

recommendedChecks.name: cors
recommendedChecks.reason: Next.js applications often have API routes that may be misconfigured for CORS. Low-cost check with high value for identifying cross-origin vulnerabilities.

recommendedChecks.name: traversal
recommendedChecks.reason: Next.js applications may expose server-side file access through dynamic routes or API handlers. Worth checking for path traversal in route parameters and Next.js specific paths.

recommendedChecks.name: redirect
recommendedChecks.reason: Next.js supports server-side redirects and middleware. Even without visible redirect parameters, testing common redirect patterns and Next.js routing mechanisms is valuable.

attackPlan.reasoning: This is a Next.js application on Vercel with no WAF detected and minimal surface area (1 page, no forms, no visible API routes). The reconnaissance shows limited endpoints, but Next.js applications often have hidden API routes and server-side functionality not immediately visible. CORS is highest priority due to common misconfigurations in Next.js API routes. Path traversal is relevant for Next.js dynamic routing and static file serving. Open redirect testing is worthwhile for Next.js redirect mechanisms. XSS and SQLi are lower priority given no forms and the limited visible attack surface.

skipReasons.xss: No forms detected and limited user input vectors visible. Next.js has built-in XSS protections through React. Better to focus on server-side vulnerabilities.
skipReasons.sqli: No forms or visible database interaction points. No API routes detected in reconnaissance. SQLi testing would have minimal value without input vectors.

validatedFindings.reasoning: Missing CSP is a legitimate security concern for a Next.js application. Without CSP, the app has no defense-in-depth against XSS attacks. This is especially important for financial applications handling sensitive data.

Missing X-Frame-Options is a valid finding for a financial application. Clickjacking attacks could trick users into performing unintended actions. Modern alternative is CSP frame-ancestors, but neither is present.
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff is a basic security header that should be present. Prevents MIME-sniffing attacks. Easy to implement in Next.js via next.config.js headers configuration.

Missing Referrer-Policy is valid but lower priority. For a finance app, if URLs contain sensitive parameters (session tokens, account IDs), this could leak data. However, modern apps typically don't put sensitive data in URLs.

Valid finding but appropriate severity. Permissions-Policy is good practice to restrict unnecessary browser features. For a finance app, explicitly disabling camera/microphone/geolocation reduces attack surface, though impact is minimal.
